lines.text: I haven't cried since I was a kid.
You cried during the World Cup.
Sober, Sharon! Sober!
Why won't you talk to me anymore?
I do talk to you!
You don't.
Yes, I do! I said hello to you yesterday!
It's a terrible shock...
What is?
Being married for 25 years, and finding out your husband's a prick.

[at a pub, after Sharon's delivery]
7 pounds 12 ounces.
Is that a baby, or a turkey?
A baby!
That's a good-sized baby.
Right.
Small turkey, though.

[to Kay, after finding nothing to watch on TV]
I suppose a ride's out of the question?
What if it's a girl, and it looks like Mr. Burgess?
Oh, shite! I guess we'll have to smother it and leave it on his step.

[trying to discover the father of Sharon's baby]
How do you know he was Spanish? Or a sailor? He could've been a Pakistani postman if you were that drunk!
Is this your first?
Yeah. Oh no, no, no. It's, uh, it's my first grandchild. Is it your first?
No, my third.
Have you read this?
[holds a Family Planning book]
Spanish, no less.
Yeah. Spanish.
An Irish sailor wasn't good enough for you, what? And will Sinbad the Spanish sailor pay for Burgess' broken window, I wonder.
What's hard and hairy on the outside? It's wet... And soft on the inside.
[in between laughs]
Jesus. It begins with a "C". It ends with a "T". And it has a "U" and an "N" in it. A co-co-co-nut. A coconut!
[crowd laughs]
Nowadays, the husband are there, with the wives, you know. I think that's much better. Cause they're able to hold our hands and, help them and encourage them, and see their child being born.
Sharon, please, I have to talk. I'm tormented!
You're tormented? You've made me the laughing stock of Barrytown, I can't go out without being jeered at. You're tormented? You prick ya!
